translated: The Tiantai Zhizhe Dashi said
Second, as for the opening and closing of various objects, first use the ten suchnesses as the head. Why is this? This sutra
Praises the ten suchnesses beyond words. Now, it further speaks of five objects. How are they the same or different?

As for the opening and closing of the twelve links of dependent arising and the ten suchnesses, they are said to be opened because the names are different, and they are said to be closed because the meanings are the same.
The link of ignorance corresponds to the suchness of nature.
The link of karmic activity corresponds to the suchness of characteristics.
The links of consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling correspond to the suchness of essence.
Craving corresponds to the suchness of conditions.
Grasping corresponds to the suchness of power and function.
Becoming corresponds to the suchness of causes.
Birth, aging, and death correspond to the suchness of effects and retributions, and so on.
Furthermore, as for the overall correspondence, the suchness of characteristics corresponds to the two links of karmic activity and becoming.
The suchness of nature corresponds to the three links of ignorance, craving, and grasping.
The suchness of essence corresponds to the seven links of consciousness, name-and-form, up to old age and death.
In this way, the power is still the three factors of the path of afflictions, ignorance, craving, and grasping, which can give rise to the power of karma.
In this way, the action is still the two factors of formations and becoming, which can create the karma for suffering.
In this way, the cause is still the two factors of formations and becoming, which serve as the causes for the seven kinds of suffering.
In this way, the condition is still the three factors of ignorance, craving, and grasping, which can nourish the karma and take on suffering.
In this way, the effect is still the habitual effect of formations and becoming.
In this way, the retribution is still the karma of formations and becoming, which attracts the retribution of name-and-form and so forth.
These two rounds are used together with the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising.
They are combined with the ten suchnesses of the six destinies.

Next, using the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising to combine with the ten suchnesses of the four holy ones, the factor of ignorance transforms and changes into understanding. Understanding is the illuminating cause, which becomes the suchness nature of the sage.
The factor of evil conduct transforms and changes into good conduct. Good conduct is the conditional cause, which becomes the suchness characteristic of the sage.
The turning of the path of suffering of consciousness, name-and-form, etc., is the Dharma body, becoming the essence of an arhat in this way.
The turning of the two factors of craving and grasping becomes the bodhi mind of an arhat, which is the power in this way.

The factor of existence, containing the effect, transforms into the practice of the six pÄramitÄs, becoming the activity of an arhat in this way, and also turns into the cause of an arhat in this way.
This turning of the factor of existence has two kinds:
The turning of the right path becomes the cause in this way, and the turning of the auxiliary path becomes the condition of an arhat in this way.
The turning of the factor of old age and death becomes the eternally abiding nature of dharmas, becoming the fruition and recompense of an arhat in this way.
Furthermore, the essence, power, and activity of the doer are simply afflictions, karma, and suffering, which transform into the Dharma body, bodhi mind, practice of the six pÄramitÄs, and so forth.

Diligent practice of the three dharmas forms the nature within, the characteristics without, the essence with right intention, the power with profound vows, the practice with establishment, the cause with attracting effects, the conditions with mutual assistance, and the fruition with accomplishment and retribution.
If divided in detail into the four noble truths, each has differences. Now taking the general outline, it is only explained in a general way.
The sutra says:
The vow for omniscience is still not lost.
The two vehicles can also be explained in a general way.
The four kinds of four noble truths combined with ten suchnesses: the two kinds of suffering and accumulation of arising and non-arising are the ten suchnesses of the six paths.
Such characteristics and such nature are accumulation.
Such essence is suffering.
Such action, power, cause, and conditions are also accumulation.
Such effects and retribution are also suffering.
The two kinds of cessation and path of arising and non-arising are the ten suchnesses of the two vehicles of analysis and essence, as well as the bodhisattvas of the Shared Teaching.
Such characteristics and nature are the path.
Such essence is cessation.
Such power, function, causes, and conditions are all the path.
Such fruits and retributions are also cessation.
The two kinds of suffering and accumulation of immeasurable and non-action are the ten suchnesses of the fruits and retributions outside the four noble truths.
The truth of accumulation is the characteristics, nature, power, function, causes, and conditions outside the realms.
The truth of suffering is the essence, fruits, retributions, and so forth outside the realms.
The two kinds of path and cessation of immeasurable and non-action are the ten suchnesses of nirvana outside the four noble truths.
The truth of the path is the nature, characteristics, power, function, causes, and conditions of nirvana, and is also prajna and liberation.
The truth of cessation is the essence, fruits, retributions, and so forth of nirvana, and also constitutes the eternally abiding Dharma body.

The four kinds of four truths combined with the four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising means that the two kinds of arising and ceasing and non-arising of suffering and accumulation are the two kinds of conceivable twelve links of dependent arising.

The two kinds of arising and ceasing and non-arising of the path and cessation are the two kinds of conceivable twelve links of dependent arising, from the cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death.
The two kinds of immeasurable and unconditioned suffering and accumulation are the two kinds of inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising.

The two kinds of immeasurable and unconditioned path and cessation are the two kinds of inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising, from the cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death. This can be understood.

The seven kinds of two truths combined with the ten suchnesses means that the four conventional [truths] of the Tripiá¹­aka, Shared, Distinct, and Perfect [Teachings], which are all the ten suchnesses of the six destinies,
the two true [truths] of the Tripiá¹­aka and Shared [Teachings] are the ten suchnesses of the two vehicles.
The two conventional [truths] of the Distinct and Perfect [Teachings], which enter the Distinct [Teaching],
the finite side is the ten suchnesses of the six destinies;
the infinite side is the ten suchnesses of the two vehicles.
The perfect conventional includes the ten suchnesses of the nine dharma realms.

The distinct entering the common, the perfect entering the common, the distinct, and the perfect entering the distinct, perfect - these five kinds of truth are all the ten suchnesses of the Buddha dharma realm.

The seven kinds of two truths combined with four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising - the common of the Tripiá¹­aka, shared, distinct, and perfect entering the common - these four conventional [truths] are the two kinds of conceivable twelve links of dependent arising.
The two truths of the Tripiá¹­aka and shared are the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising, from the cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death.
The two conventional [truths] of the distinct entering the distinct are:
The limited side is the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising;
The unlimited side is the conceivable cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death.
The perfect conventional includes the four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising within and outside the three realms.
The five kinds of true suchness are the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising beyond the three realms, from the cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death.
The combination of the seven kinds of two truths with the four kinds of four noble truths means that the two truths of real existence correspond to the four noble truths of arising and ceasing.
The two truths of illusory existence correspond to the four noble truths of non-arising.
The two conventional truths of entering the shared from the distinct and entering the shared from the perfect still correspond to the suffering and accumulation of non-arising.
The true suchness of entering the shared from the distinct is the immeasurable path and cessation.
The true suchness of entering the shared from the perfect is the path and cessation of no more training.
The conventional truth of the distinct and the conventional truth of entering the distinct from the perfect correspond to the immeasurable suffering and accumulation.
The perfect conventional truth corresponds to the suffering and accumulation of no more training.ğŸ”½The true suchness of the distinct corresponds to the immeasurable path and cessation.
The true suchness of entering the distinct from the perfect and the perfect true suchness correspond to the path and cessation of no more training.

The five kinds of three truths combined with the ten suchnesses: the two conventional [truths] of the distinct and the integrated, and the distinct conventional [truth] of the integrated, are the ten suchnesses of the six destinies.
The distinct conventional [truth] and the conventional [truth] of the integrated within the distinct, with a boundary, are the ten suchnesses of the six destinies;
without a boundary, they are the ten suchnesses of the two vehicles.
The conventional [truth] of the perfect, the meaning is generally applicable to the nine realms and so forth.
The five kinds of ultimate truth are all the ten suchnesses of the two vehicles, bodhisattvas, and so forth;
the five kinds of middle truth are all the ten suchnesses of the Buddha realm.

The five kinds of three truths combined with the four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising: the two conventional [truths] of the distinct and the integrated, and the distinct conventional [truth] of the integrated, are the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising of the six destinies.
The two conventional [truths] of the distinct and the integrated within the distinct:
with a boundary, they are the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising giving rise to the six destinies;
without a boundary, they are the conceivable cessation of the twelve links of dependent arising.
The conventional [truth] of the perfect, the meaning is generally applicable and so forth.

Now, using these four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising, the five kinds of true aspects are precisely the cessation of the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising, and also the arising of the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising.
The five kinds of middle truth are precisely the cessation of the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising.

The combination of the five kinds of three truths and the four kinds of four truths is as follows: The two conventional [truths] of the distinct and the perfect entering the common [truth] are the non-arising of suffering and accumulation.

The distinct conventional [truth], the perfect entering the distinct conventional [truth], and the perfect conventional [truth] are all the non-arising of suffering and accumulation, and also the non-arising of the path and cessation, and also the immeasurable suffering and accumulation.

The two truths of the distinct and the perfect entering the common [truth] originally grasp only the side of emptiness, which is the non-arising path and cessation.ğŸ”½The distinct truth and the perfect entering the distinct truth are precisely the non-arising path and cessation, and within the immeasurable [truth] they are suffering and accumulation.
The perfect truth, within the non-arising [truth] it is the path and cessation, and within the immeasurable [truth] and the truth of non-action it is suffering and accumulation.
Entering the Distinct within the Shared is the extinction of the path of immeasurability.
Entering the Perfect within the Shared is the extinction of the path of non-action.
Within the Distinct, it is the extinction of the path of immeasurability.
Entering the Perfect within the Distinct is the extinction of the path of non-action.
Within the Perfect, it is precisely the extinction of the path of non-action.
The five kinds of three truths combined with the seven kinds of two truths distinguish the previous two kinds of two truths that are not combined.
Next, the two kinds of two truths, the two conventional, are the five kinds of conventional within the five kinds of three truths.
The two truths, the empty side, are the five kinds of true within the five kinds of three truths;
The non-empty side is within the five kinds of three truths.
The last three kinds of two truths, the three conventional, the empty side is the five kinds of true within the five kinds of three truths;
The existent side is the five kinds of conventional within the five kinds of three truths.
The three truths are within the five kinds of three truths.
Another kind of explanation is that the latter two truths are not combined, and the latter five conventional truths have both truth and convention;
The latter five truths have both truth and the middle.
As for combining the one true truth with the ten suchnesses, each dharma realm is endowed with the ten realms, excluding the other nine realms, and is the same as only the Buddha realm.
Excluding the three kinds of twelve links of dependent arising, it is the same as only the cessation of the one kind of twelve links of dependent arising.
Excluding the three kinds of four noble truths, it is the same as only the one true four noble truths.
Excluding the seven kinds of two truths, it is the same as only the five true truths, with some similarities and differences.

Excluding the five kinds of three truths, it is the same as only the five middle truths.ğŸ”½As for saying that the truth of non-existence cannot be spoken of, combining the ten suchnesses means that suchness is not different, which is emptiness and quiescence.
Words and appearances are quiescent and extinguished, and cannot be spoken or shown, which is the meaning of the ten being suchnesses.
The meaning of the cessation of ignorance up to the cessation of old age and death is very profound, and profound means the same as no truth.
The unborn cannot be spoken of, up to the non-unborn cannot be spoken of, which is the same as no truth.
The seven kinds of true reality are all inexpressible.
The first true reality that cannot be spoken of is like what ÅšÄriputra said:
I have heard that within liberation there is no speech.
How much less the latter six?
Neither saá¹ƒsÄra nor nirvÄá¹‡a, being neither of the two extremes also has no middle way, which is the same as no truth as the five kinds of middle truth.
One reality is called empty space, and empty space has no one, so how can there be reality?
Which is the same as no truth.
No truth itself has no existence, and the great wisdom of equality has no distinctions.
Although there are no distinctions, the immeasurable distinctions fill the Dharma realm, and one does not know where they come from.
Immeasurable and without distinction, collecting them, one does not know what they have, and does not know where they come from.
Not coming and not going, this is the Dharma Buddha.

Furthermore, the seven kinds of two truths, responding to conditions and opening and closing, turning and entering each other, each also has according to feelings, according to feelings and wisdom, according to wisdom, and so on.
The other five meanings should also have this, but are not fully recorded now.
What is it?
The Buddha expounds the Dharma with one voice, and sentient beings understand it according to their kind.
Think about it yourself!
Question:
Since the principles of all realms are already fused, why do the various teachings, like blooming flowers, further restrict and enter each other?
Answer:
The TathÄgata observes and knows the nature and characteristics of the ten realms, some are mature and some are not.
Those with great capacity who are not yet mature are prevented from giving rise to slander;
Those with small capacity who are mature are prevented from missing the opportunity.
According to their suitability, whether single or combined, the biased and perfect interpenetrate and mature them, and upon hearing they gain benefits.
Although the Huayan Sutra also examines the ten realms, the two realms of the two vehicles are ripe, so it uses the two kinds of distinct and perfect teachings to mature them.
The Tripiá¹­aka also examines the ten realms, and the natures and characteristics of the two vehicles are ripe, so it uses arising and ceasing to mature them.

The Vaipulya also examines the ten realms, and the four realms of the two vehicles and the two vehicles of the Distinct Teaching are ripe, so it uses the four kinds of mutual interpenetration to mature them.

The PrajÃ±Ä also examines the ten realms, and the four realms of the two vehicles and the two vehicles of the Distinct Teaching are ripe, so it uses the three kinds of mutual interpenetration to mature them.

The Lotus SÅ«tra also examines the ten realms, and the one nature and characteristics of the two vehicles and the two vehicles of the Distinct Teaching are ripe, so it uses the one perfect truth to mature them.
If there were no skillful means of emerging and entering to tame and mature, how could the objects and wisdom be fused into wondrousness?

It is like a painter who can still blend the five colors to create various images, let alone the Dharma King of the Buddha who has mastery over the Dharma, and cannot use various kinds of interpenetration to tame and subdue sentient beings?
Question:
Above it is explained that the six objects, etc., this sÅ«tra is inaudible and acceptable, does it have its meaning or not?
Answer:
The names and meanings of the ten suchnesses have already been fully explained before.
As for the four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising, the chapter on the City of Dharma clarifies the twelve links of dependent arising that arise and cease.
The chapter on Parables only speaks of being free from delusion, which is the twelve links of dependent arising that do not arise.
The chapter on Skillful Means states:
The Buddha's lineage arises from conditions, which are the two kinds of twelve links of dependent arising beyond the realm of existence, immeasurable and unconditioned.
As for the four kinds of four noble truths, the chapter on Parables states that the cause of all suffering is rooted in craving, which are the four noble truths that arise and cease.
The chapter on Simile of the Herbs states that penetratingly understanding the Dharma of emptiness is the four noble truths that do not arise.

It also states the unsurpassed path, and the chapter on Skillful Means only speaks of the unsurpassed path, such as the TathÄgata's nirvÄá¹‡a, which are the two kinds of four noble truths beyond the realm of existence, immeasurable and unconditioned.
The distinctions in the ten suchnesses are the conventional truth.
Only the Buddhas, together with the Buddhas, are able to thoroughly investigate the true characteristics of all dharmas, which is the ultimate truth.
The Chapter on Peaceful Practices states:
One does not discriminate between conditioned and unconditioned, real and unreal dharmas.
Existence is the conventional truth;
Non-existence is the ultimate truth;
Not discriminating is to block the two extremes and reveal the middle way.
The Chapter on Life-span states:
Neither the same nor different. Not different is not the conventional; not the same is not the ultimate. This is the meaning of the three truths.
The Chapter on Skillful Means states:
Using other skillful means to reveal the ultimate truth.
This is the one true reality.
It also states:
This is the only true reality.

If it is said that the Dharma of non-discrimination is taught, and the characteristic of the quiescence of all dharmas cannot be expressed in words, then this is the meaning of the truth of non-existence.
â—‹ Second, the marvelous wisdom is as follows: The profound truth is subtle and cannot be revealed without wisdom;
Wisdom can know the object, and without the object it cannot be integrated.

Since the objects are already fused and wondrous, the wisdom also accords with them, just like a shadow following a form or an echo following a sound. Therefore, after discussing the objects, it explains the wisdom.
The wisdom is divided into two parts:
First, a general discussion of various wisdoms; second, discussing wisdom in relation to objects.
The general wisdom is divided into six parts:
First, enumeration;
Second, classification;
Third, characteristics;
Fourth, illumination;
Fifth, judgment;
Sixth, opening up.
As for enumeration:
First, worldly wisdom.
Second, the wisdom of the four foundations of mindfulness and the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
Third, the wisdom of the four roots of goodness.
Fourth, the wisdom of the four fruits.
Fifth, the wisdom of the pratyekabuddhas.
Sixth, the wisdom of the six perfections.
Seventh, the wisdom of the Å›rÄvakas who understand the nature of dharmas.

Eighth, the wisdom of the pratyekabuddhas who understand the nature of dharmas.ğŸ”½Ninth, the wisdom of the bodhisattvas who enter the truth through skillful means and understand the nature of dharmas.
Tenth, the wisdom of the bodhisattvas who emerge from the provisional and understand the nature of dharmas.
Eleventh, the wisdom of the ten faiths in the separate teaching.
Twelfth, the wisdom of the thirty minds.
Thirteenth, the wisdom of the ten grounds.
Fourteenth, the wisdom of the Buddha of the Tripiá¹­aka.
Fifteenth, the wisdom of the Buddha of the Shared Teaching.
Sixteenth, the wisdom of the Buddha of the Distinct Teaching.
Seventeenth, the wisdom of the disciples of the five ranks of the Perfect Teaching.
Eighteenth, the wisdom of the purification of the six sense faculties.
Nineteenth, the wisdom from the initial abode to equal enlightenment.
Twentieth, the wisdom of wondrous enlightenment.
Second, as for the categories, worldly wisdom lacks the Way, with false calculations and delusions, the mind operates outside of principle, not believing or entering, thus it is one.
The five contemplations and the four establishments of mindfulness have already entered the initial sages and the Buddha's Dharma, all being outer worthies, thus it is one.
The four good roots are all inner worthies, thus it is one.
The four fruits are the same in seeing the truth, thus it is one.

The pratyekabuddha's observation of specific characteristics can erode habits, thus it is one.ğŸ”½The six perfections have weak understanding of principle and strong understanding of phenomena, thus it is one.
The expedient Å›rÄvakas of the Shared Teaching have superior understanding of the essence of dharmas, thus it is one.
The pratyekabuddhas are slightly superior, so they are one.
The bodhisattvas of the Shared Teaching enter the expedient wisdom of the truth, and study the four approaches extensively, so they are one.
The wisdom of the bodhisattvas of the Shared Teaching who manifest in the conventional world is precisely the contemplation of the conventional, so they are one.
The wisdom of the ten faiths of the Distinct Teaching first knows the Middle Way, surpassing the previous and being inferior to the later, so they are one.
The thirty minds of the Distinct Teaching are all ordinary beings, so they are one.
The ten grounds are all the wisdom of sages, so they are one.
The Buddha of the Tripiá¹­aka Teaching is the position of a teacher, surpassing the disciples of the three vehicles, so they are one.
The wisdom of the Buddha of the Shared Teaching surpasses in cutting through delusions and illuminating the capacities of sentient beings, so they are one.
The wisdom of the Buddha of the Distinct Teaching is even more superior, so they are one.
The disciples of the five ranks of the Perfect Teaching are the same in possessing the nature of afflictions, yet able to know the secret treasury of the TathÄgata, so they are one.
The wisdom of the pure six sense faculties is adjacent to the truth, so they are one.
From the initial abode up to equal enlightenment, they are the same in destroying ignorance, so they are one.
The Buddha's wisdom of wondrous enlightenment is unsurpassed and most revered, so it is considered one.
In this way, those of similar categories are either separated or combined, divided into twenty, and so on.
Third, as for distinguishing their characteristics, the worldly wisdom of India extends to the state of non-perception.

What is upheld here is primarily loyalty, filial piety, the five actions, the six arts, astronomy, geography, medical prescriptions, divination, military strategy, economic policies, and the recognition of the thousands of plants and the knowledge of the myriad species of birds and beasts.
Moreover, cutting the left and sparing the right, without aversion or attachment.

Attaining the fundamental samÄdhi, manifesting the five supernatural powers, stopping the river in one's ears, transforming Åšakra into a sheep, inhaling and exhaling wind and clouds, touching the sun and moon with one's hands.
The Dharma is a worldly dharma, the samÄdhi is an immovable samÄdhi, and the wisdom is an immovable emergence.
Seeking fame and profit, increasing views and attachments, known by the worldly mind, thus it is called worldly wisdom.
The five cessations and four mindfulnesses: because there is concentration, they are called cessations; because there is wisdom, they are called contemplations.
Contemplation can overturn wrong views, concentration can restrain chaos.
Counting the breath treats distraction, impurity treats greed, nourishing treats anger, dependent origination treats delusion, mindfulness of the Buddha treats obstacles to the path.
The foundations of mindfulness are the four knowledges above the contemplation of the truth of suffering, treating the four inverted views.
The four inverted views do not arise from these four contemplations.
First overturning the four inverted views, not yet entering the principle of sagehood, therefore it is called the wisdom of the outer ordinary person.
The stage of heat gives rise to knowledge that takes the four truths as its object, subdues afflictions, and further increases knowledge, forming the sixteen contemplations of knowledge.
Like fire drilling, the upper and lower parts rely on each other to produce fire and burn firewood.
Having knowledge that knows existence and objects, it can give rise to the knowledge of heat, causing existence to wither.
Like a pile of flowers in the summer, the flowers produce heat and wither themselves.

Moreover, based on the aggregates and contemplating the aggregates, the fire of wisdom arises and burns the aggregates, like two bamboos rubbing together to produce fire, which then burns the bamboo grove.
The Venerable Ghosha said:
The fire of wisdom seeking liberation is the first stage of heat.
Just as fire has smoke as its initial characteristic,
the fire of uncontaminated wisdom also has the dharma of heat as its initial characteristic.
Just as the sun has the characteristic of light as its initial characteristic, therefore it is called heat.
Those who give rise to faith, love, and respect for the true Dharma and Vinaya, in relation to the truth of the path, and those who have faith in the Vinaya, in relation to the truth of cessation,
how can it be said that the two have faith in heat that can relate to the four truths?
The answer:
these two are the most excellent and should be explained first.
Moreover, the true Dharma is the three truths, and the Vinaya is the truth of cessation.
As the Buddha said to Manjushri:
I have four phrases of Dharma that I will explain to you. Do you wish to know?
You may do as you please.
The four phrases are the four truths.
All giving and upholding precepts are directed towards liberation, this is its intention.
The arising of the form realm concentration is its basis.
The wholesome roots that arise before one's own stage are its similar causes.
The peak is its effect of human effort with regard to the four noble truths.
The wholesome roots that arise later and are similar to one's own stage are its effect of dominance.
The form realm five aggregates are its retribution.
The definite cause of nirvana and the unbroken wholesome roots are its benefit.
The sixteen aspects are its practice, its arising from conditions, and its cultivation of wisdom.
The three samÄdhis bound to the form realm, the three faculties as explained, the many associated minds, are its regression.
There are three kinds of heat:
namely, lower-lower, lower-middle, and lower-upper.
There are three kinds of summit:
middle-lower, middle-middle, and middle-upper.
There are two kinds of patience:
lower-upper and upper-middle.
There is one kind of supreme worldly dharmas:
namely, upper-upper.
These four roots of goodness, when spoken of in terms of three, are as follows: heat is the lowest, summit is middling, and forbearance and the supreme worldly dharmas are the highest.
There are also those who say:
Heat has two:
namely, lowest-lowest and lowest-middling.
The summit has three:
namely, lowest-highest, middling-lowest, and middling-middling.
Forbearance has three:
namely, middling-highest, lowest-highest, and highest-middling.
The supreme worldly dharmas have one:
namely, highest-highest.

When also spoken of in terms of three, the heat dharma is lowest-lowest, the summit dharma is lowest-middling, the forbearance dharma is middling-highest, and the supreme worldly dharma is highest-highest.
Gosa says:
Heat has three lowest [levels], the summit has six:
from lowest-lowest up to middling-highest.
Forbearance has eight:
from lowest-lowest up to highest-middling.
The supreme worldly dharmas only have the highest-highest.
When spoken of in terms of three, the heat dharma is of one kind, namely the lowest.
The summit dharma is of two kinds, namely the lowest and the middling.
There are three kinds of patience, namely, lower, middle, and upper.
The supreme worldly dharmas have one kind, namely, upper.
Heat has two kinds of abandonment:
First, leaving the realm and ground, second, at the time of regression.
Abandonment at the time of regression falls into hell, commits the five heinous crimes, but does not sever the roots of goodness.
The peak is also like this.
Patience has only one abandonment, not falling into hell and so on.
The peak dharma is the wholesome roots of the form realm, which are moving and unmoving, abiding and not abiding, difficult and not difficult, severed and not severed, regressing and not regressing.
As for moving up to regressing, there are two:
The lower is heat, the upper is the peak.
The unmoving up to the non-regressing are two:
The lower is patience, the upper is the supreme worldly dharmas.
Furthermore, there are those who say it should be said to be the lower peak.
Why is it so?
Because it is at the peak of the heat dharma, it is called the peak.
Because it is below the stage of patience, it is called lower.
There are also those who say that it is like a mountain path where people do not stay long.
If there are no difficulties, one will definitely pass through this and reach the other side;
if one encounters difficulties, one will immediately retreat.
The practitioner does not stay long at the peak, if there are no difficulties, one will definitely reach patience;
if there are difficulties, one will retreat to the warmth.
It is like the peak of a mountain, therefore it is called the peak.
What is meant by contemplation?
Giving rise to a small amount of faith in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
A small amount of faith means this Dharma does not stay for long, therefore it is called small.
This faith arises from the Buddha and gives rise to a small amount of faith, this is taking the truth of the path as the object.
Giving rise to a small amount of faith in the Dharma, this is taking the truth of cessation as the object.
Question:
One should be able to take the four truths as the object, why is it said to take two truths as the object?
Answer:
Because the path and cessation are superior.
Pure and without fault, this is wonderful, this is liberation.
Able to give rise to faith, in order to give rise to the faithful and joyful mind of those who receive and practice.
If the World-Honored One says that suffering and its cause are to be trusted and respected, then there will be no one to accept the teachings.
How can these afflictions, evil conduct, wrong views, and inversions be respected and trusted?
I am always oppressed by this.
Those who accept the teachings delight in the path and cessation, therefore, the two are explained.
Furthermore, some say that trusting the Buddha and Sangha is the condition for the path, and trusting the Dharma is the condition for the three truths, thus exhausting the trust in the four truths.
Question:
Those abiding at the peak also trust the aggregates, also trust the treasures, also trust the truths.
Why only speak of trusting the Three Treasures?
Answer:
The Three Treasures are the place of giving rise to trust and respect.
It is simply according to the practitioner's mind, giving rise to delight in the aggregates, which is called heat.
Giving rise to delight in the treasures, this is called the peak.
Giving rise to delight in the truths, this is called forbearance.
Question:
Why does one regress from the peak, but not speak of regressing from heat?
Answer:
Since the peak can retrogress, it should also be said that heat can retrogress.
When the practitioner is at the peak, there are many afflictions and karma that create obstacles.
The afflictions and so forth think:
If the practitioner reaches acceptance, in whose body will I create karmic retribution again?
When leaving the desire realm, they also think:
When the practitioner leaves the desire realm, in whose body will I give rise to karmic retribution?
When leaving the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, they also think:
After the practitioner leaves the desire for that, they will no longer take on a body. In whose body will I give rise to karmic retribution?
At these three times, there are many obstacles.
Because of the obstacles and retrogressing, there is great worry and distress.
It is like a person who sees a treasure trove and is greatly delighted, but then suddenly loses it.
The one abiding in the peak stage thinks to themselves:
Before long I will attain acceptance, permanently sever the evil destinies, and obtain the great heavy benefit, just like an arhat.
But suddenly losing it, therefore there is great worry and distress. Therefore it is said that the peak can retrogress.

If one can draw near to good friends, listen to the teachings of skillful means from them, contemplate correctly within one's mind, believe in the Buddha's enlightenment, believe in the well-expounded Dharma, and believe in the pure merits of the Saá¹…gha, this is said to be believing in the treasures.
Explaining that form is impermanent, up to explaining that consciousness is impermanent, this is said to be believing in the aggregates.
Knowing there is suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path, this is said to be believing in the truths.
If it is like this, one abides at the peak. If it is not like this, one falls back from the peak.
The contemplation of the stage of patience is the correct contemplation of the suffering of the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm.
The accumulation of practices in the desire realm, the accumulation of practices in the form realm, and the accumulation of practices in the formless realm.
The cessation of practices in the desire realm, the cessation of practices in the form realm, and the cessation of practices in the formless realm.
The path that cuts off practices in the desire realm, the path that cuts off practices in the form realm, and the path that cuts off practices in the formless realm.
Thirty-two such minds are called the lower patience.

Later, the practitioner gradually reduces practice and conditions, and again correctly contemplates the suffering of the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm, up to contemplating the path that eliminates the practices of the desire realm, excluding the contemplation that eliminates the practices of the form and formless realms. From this point on, it is called middle acceptance.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm, the suffering of the form and formless realms, up to contemplating the cessation of the practices of the form and formless realms, excluding all paths.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm, up to contemplating the cessation of the practices of the desire realm, excluding the cessation of the practices of the form and formless realms.
Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm, up to contemplating the accumulation of the practices of the form and formless realms, excluding all cessations.

Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm, up to contemplating the accumulation of the practices of the desire realm, excluding the accumulation of the practices of the form and formless realms.
Again, correctly contemplate the suffering of the desire realm, the form realm, and the formless realm, excluding all accumulations.
Again, correctly contemplating the suffering of the desire realm, excluding the suffering of the form and formless realms.
Again, correctly contemplating the permanence of the desire realm, continuously without interruption, not far removed.

When contemplating in this way, deeply giving rise to disgust and aversion, further reducing and diminishing, only making two minds contemplate one aspect, like the receptivity to the cognition of dharmas regarding suffering.
Correctly contemplating in this way is called middling receptivity.
Again, with one mind contemplating the suffering of the desire realm, this is called upper receptivity.
Next, giving rise to the supreme worldly dharmas, after the supreme worldly dharmas, next giving rise to the receptivity to the cognition of dharmas regarding suffering.
It is like a person who wishes to go from their own country to another country, with much wealth and property, unable to take it with them, exchanging the goods for money;
Still dissatisfied with the money, exchanging it for gold;
Dissatisfied with the gold, exchanging it for more valuable jewels, going to the other country.
The practitioner gradually abandons up to the continuity not being separated, giving rise to the upper receptivity.
After the upper receptivity, giving rise to the supreme worldly dharmas.
After the supreme worldly dharmas, the acceptance of suffering arises.
Question:
Are there three grades of supreme worldly dharmas?
Answer:
One person has none, many people have them.
UpaÌ„li is superior, MaudgalyÄyana is middling, the rest are all inferior.
From the perspective of Buddhas, Pratyekabuddhas, and SÌraÌ„vakas, they are divided into three grades.
The supreme worldly dharmas, these mind and mental factors, are the best, most excellent, longest, most venerable, highest, and most wonderful among other dharmas.
They are also divided and also universal.
The divided [supreme worldly dharmas] surpass worldly dharmas, but do not surpass the view of the truths.
The retinue of the view of the truths is inseparable, because the power of wisdom is predominant, and because the meditation perfumed does not share the same place of birth with ordinary beings.
At the time of the knowledge of exhaustion, all wholesome roots are permanently free from all defilements and hindrances.
The three samÄdhis, up to the despised and impure, how much more so the contaminated, should not surpass [the supreme worldly dharmas] universally.

It is also said to be superior to the heat, summit, and forbearance dharmas. It should be said to be the foremost, and it should be said to be superior. It is superior to the dharmas of heat, summit, and forbearance, and to the dhyÄna, immeasurables, liberations, and spheres attained by all ordinary beings.
Or it is said to be completely superior, but this does not mean it is superior in all activities. It is only because it can open the door to the holy path.

The truths of seeing and so forth cannot open the door to the holy path. It is the supreme worldly dharma that opens the door to the holy path. The dharmas of seeing the truths and so forth are attained.
The attainment of cultivation is all due to the power of the supreme worldly dharma.
As for the meaning of the supreme worldly dharma, the meaning of supreme is the meaning of first;
attaining the wonderful fruit is the meaning of first, just as the top of a tall banner has nothing above it, this is the meaning of first.
Question:
Are there distinctions among the previous meanings?
Answer:
These all praise and speak of the meaning of supreme excellence, and there are also distinctions.

In terms of impurity and mindfulness of breathing, it is called the best; in terms of hearing wisdom, it is called superior; in terms of thinking wisdom, it is called long; in terms of heat, it is called venerable; in terms of summit, it is called supreme; in terms of patience, it is called wonderful.

Moreover, relying on the stage of non-entry is the best; relying on the first dhyÄna is superior; the intermediate state is long; the second dhyÄna is venerable; the third dhyÄna is supreme; the fourth dhyÄna is wonderful.
Such various explanations are based on the VibhÄá¹£Ä commentary. If you want to know in detail, look there.
The first fruit is the eight forbearances and eight knowledges.
The third fruit is the nine unobstructed and nine liberated knowledges that repeatedly contemplate the truth.

The pratyekabuddha uses general characteristics and specific characteristics. For example, in terms of the three times, he clarifies suffering and accumulation, and distinguishes the twelve links of dependent arising, which are the specific characteristics.
The wisdom of the six pÄramitÄs that relies on the principle of reality is weak, so it is subdued but not yet eliminated;
The wisdom of phenomena is strong, so it can give up one's body, life, and wealth without any attachment.

The Å›rÄvakas are able to give rise to the true and become sages, yet they still discuss my robe and my alms bowl, and argue with each other about their relative strengths and weaknesses.ğŸ”½The Å›rÄvakas of the Shared Teaching, through the one aspect of the general characteristics, penetrate the conventional and realize the true.
The pratyekabuddhas of the Shared Teaching are able to, through the general and specific characteristics of the one aspect, penetrate the conventional and realize the true.
The bodhisattvas of the Shared Teaching are able to, through the general and specific characteristics of the four aspects, penetrate the conventional and realize the true.
They are also able to, through the four aspects, manifest in the conventional world and teach and transform sentient beings.
The ten stages of faith believe in the true suchness of the fruition-head, which is the true reality. In order to seek this principle, they give rise to the ten stages of faith.

The ten abodes correctly cultivate entry into emptiness, while indirectly cultivating the conventional and the middle.ğŸ”½The ten practices correctly cultivate the conventional, while indirectly cultivating the middle.
The ten dedications correctly cultivate the middle.
The first ground realizes the middle;
The second ground and above, repeatedly contemplate the middle.
The Buddha of the Tripiá¹­aka Teaching uses thirty-four mental states at one time:
Eight forbearances, eight knowledges, nine unobstructed [paths], and nine liberated [paths], eliminating both the afflictive hindrances and the cognitive hindrances.
The Shared Teaching says that when the Buddha sits at the site of enlightenment, with the wisdom of a single thought, he cuts off the remaining habitual propensities.
The Distinct Teaching says that the Buddha uses the mind after the vajra to cut off the final bit of ignorance and become a Buddha.
Some say:
When cutting off, it is the stage of equal enlightenment.
The Buddha has nothing to cut off, but only realizes perfect enlightenment and is fully endowed.
The Perfect Teaching says that those in the five ranks do not cut off the five desires but purify the faculties, possess the nature of afflictions, and can know the secret treasury of the TathÄgata.
Those in the stage of the pure six faculties attain the wisdom of the semblance middle way.
Those in the initial abode attain the TathÄgata's one body and innumerable bodies, enter the ocean of the Dharma stream, and flow spontaneously.
The later stages can be understood and need not be recorded again.

Fourth, clarifying the wisdom that illuminates the realm: If the wisdom illuminates the realm, and the realm gives rise to wisdom, the four statements all fall into the nature, as recorded separately.
If the realm and wisdom are established based on the four siddhÄntas, there are only names.
Question:
Can the object also illuminate the cognition?
Answer:
If we give an inconceivable explanation, they mutually illuminate each other, and the meaning is also unobstructed.
The PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra of the Benevolent Kings says:
Speaking of cognition and the domain of cognition are all called prajÃ±Ä.
It is like a mirror and its surface mutually reflecting each other, or like the earth producing various sprouts, and the sprouts also producing the earth.
Let us set aside this discussion for now.
The worldly cognition illuminates the ten suchnesses of the six destinies.
The cognition of the five methods of calming the mind goes up to the contemplation of the essence of dharmas. The seven cognitions illuminate the ten suchnesses of the two vehicles.

The cognition of the bodhisattvas who practice the six pÄramitÄs and the provisional teachings belongs to both. Seeking above, it illuminates the ten suchnesses of the bodhisattvas; transforming below, it illuminates the ten suchnesses of the six destinies.
The cognition of the forty stages also belongs to both:
Seeking above, it illuminates the ten suchnesses of the bodhisattvas; transforming below, it illuminates the ten suchnesses of the six destinies.
The cognition of the ten grounds belongs to both: sequentially illuminating, it illuminates the ten suchnesses of the bodhisattvas;
It does not illuminate in sequence, but illuminates the ten suchnesses of the Buddha.
From the five categories onward, the four kinds of wisdom all illuminate the ten suchnesses of the Buddha realm.
The summary is like this, the detailed analysis is explained in the text.

As for the twenty kinds of wisdom illuminating the four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising, the worldly wisdom, the five cessations, the four mindfulnesses, the four fruits, up to the pratyekabuddha, the six perfections, and the wisdom of the Tripiá¹­aka Buddha, these seven kinds of wisdom illuminate the conceivable twelve links of dependent arising that arise and cease.

The wisdom of the expedient entry into truth of the three vehicles of the Shared Teaching, the wisdom of emerging from the provisional, and the wisdom of the Buddha, these five kinds of wisdom illuminate the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising that do not arise or cease.

The wisdom of the ten faiths, the thirty minds, the ten grounds, and the Buddha of the Distinct Teaching, these four kinds of wisdom illuminate the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising that arise and cease.
There are distinctions within this, but for now I will follow the general classification.
The four kinds of wisdom of the Perfect Teaching illuminate the inconceivable twelve links of dependent arising that do not arise or cease.
As for the twenty kinds of cognition illuminating the four kinds of four truths, the first seven cognitions illuminate the realm of the four truths of arising and ceasing.
Next, the five cognitions illuminate the realm of the four truths of non-arising and non-ceasing.
Next, the four cognitions illuminate the realm of the four truths of immeasurability.
Next, the four cognitions illuminate the realm of the four truths of non-action.
Next, as for the twenty cognitions illuminating the two truths, the first seven cognitions are the illumination of the two truths of empty analysis.
Next, the five cognitions are the illumination of the two truths of empty essence.
Next, the eight cognitions illuminate the two truths revealed in the middle.
The mutual inclusion of the distinct and perfect teachings can be understood in this way.

Next, as for clarifying the twenty cognitions illuminating the three truths, the first seven cognitions illuminate the two truths without the middle, which are all conditioned phenomena included in the conventional truth.
Next, the five cognitions illuminate the two truths that contain the middle, which are all included in the truth of emptiness.

Next, the eight wisdoms of the Distinct and Perfect Vehicles illuminate the two truths within the Middle, which are also called provisional names, and are also called the Middle Way. Both phrases are included in the Middle Truth.
Next, the twenty wisdoms illuminate the One Real Truth. This requires citing the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom to clarify the four siddhÄntas, all of which are called real.
Because of the worldly realm, it is real, up to because of the ultimate truth, it is real.

One should know that the real teaching also extends to the four truths. Because of arising and ceasing, it is real. Because of non-arising and non-ceasing, it is real. Because of immeasurability, it is real. Because of non-action, it is real.
The first, the seven wisdoms of the Tripiá¹­aka Vehicle, illuminate the reality of arising and ceasing.
Next, the five wisdoms of the Shared Teaching illuminate the reality of non-arising and non-ceasing.
Next, the four wisdoms of the Distinct Teaching illuminate the reality of immeasurability.
Next, the four wisdoms of the Perfect Teaching illuminate the reality of non-action.
The realities before and after are explained in detail.

Next, the twenty kinds of cognition have no truth and no illumination. There is no truth and no separate principle. If one attains enlightenment in the four kinds of four truths, one no longer sees truth and untruth, so having no truth is also comprehensive.
The first seven kinds of cognition illuminate the truthlessness of arising and ceasing, because arising and arising cannot be spoken of.
Next, the five kinds of cognition illuminate the truthlessness of non-arising and non-ceasing, because arising and non-arising cannot be spoken of.
Next, the four kinds of cognition illuminate the truthlessness of the immeasurable, because non-arising and arising cannot be spoken of.
Next, the four kinds of cognition illuminate the truthlessness of the unconditioned, because non-arising and non-non-arising cannot be spoken of.
The former truthlessness is provisional, and the latter truthlessness is real. This is based on the spoken teachings.
If based on the wondrous enlightenment that is the same as what is illuminated in the minds of the sages, then one does not see any provisional or real, so it is neither provisional nor real.
An empty fist deceives small children, guiding and liberating all.
Provisionally speaking of the provisional, provisionally speaking of the real.
When one unifies the principles, there are no more provisional or real, therefore it is called the wondrous that is neither provisional nor real.
Fifth, clarifying the coarse and wondrous: the first twelve kinds of wisdom are coarse, and the last eight kinds of wisdom are wondrous.
Why is this?

The buddhas of the Tripiá¹­aka, Shared, and other teachings are themselves impermanent, and do not speak of permanence. How could the two vehicles and bodhisattvas hear permanence, believe in permanence, and cultivate permanence?
Therefore, it is coarse.
The ten abodes of the Distinct Teaching have already heard permanence from the beginning, and believe in and cultivate permanence, which is still superior to those buddhas, let alone the others.
Therefore, it is wondrous.
The usual explanation says:
The Lotus SÅ«tra does not clarify permanence, it is only the meaning of the Tripiá¹­aka.
Now, it is clarified that the ten abodes know that the middle has already surpassed the sage, and the eight kinds are wondrous.
Moreover, the four wisdoms of the Distinct Teaching are three coarse and one wondrous.
The four wisdoms of the Perfect Teaching are all called wondrous.
Why is this?
The people of the grounds say:
The middle way is the fruition that can reveal. Beginners should look up to and believe in this principle, like a mountain suspended by a lotus thread.
Therefore, it is said that both faith and practice are not the perfect meaning.
Therefore, the wisdom of the ten faiths is coarse.ğŸ”½The ten abodes mainly cultivate emptiness, and secondarily cultivate the provisional and the middle.
The ten practices mainly cultivate the provisional, and secondarily cultivate the middle.
The ten dedications begin to mainly cultivate the middle.
Here, it is only principle, not endowed with all dharmas, and therefore it is all coarse.
The wisdom of the stages of the ten grounds breaks through ignorance, sees the middle way, and realizes it as wonderful.
It is similar to the two types of thorough and hidden, both attaining the way, but the three hidden gates are clumsy.
Now the separate teaching is also like this, the teaching gates are all provisional, but the realization is wonderful.

The four wisdoms of the perfect teaching are all wonderful. As explained in the characteristics of dharmas, as explained and believed, as principle and practiced, starting from the five ranks, finally to the wonderful enlightenment, it is real and not provisional, and therefore all wonderful.
This is called the coarse wisdom that is said to be the wonderful wisdom.
Furthermore, in terms of knowledge and insight, what is coarse and what is wonderful?
There are four kinds of distinctions:
not knowing and not seeing, knowing but not seeing, seeing but not knowing, and both knowing and seeing.
First, explain the Tripiá¹­aka, and then explain the perfect teaching. The examples in between can be understood.
Ordinary people do not hear, so they do not know, and they do not realize, so they do not see.
The five cessations and four contemplations up to the supreme worldly dharmas, hearing is called knowing, but not realizing is not seeing.
Pratyekabuddhas do not hear, so they do not know, but they naturally realize, so they see.
The four fruits hear, so they also know, and they realize, so they also see.
Distinguishing the coarse and wonderful one by one can be understood.
In terms of explaining the perfect teaching, the seven expedient means do not hear, so they do not know, and they have not realized, so they do not see.
The five grades and six faculties hear, so they know, but they have not realized, so they do not see.
Those who give rise to past habits are called seers, because they do not learn from others, they do not know.
Those who receive the teachings and realize them also know and see.
This is passed down as coarse and subtle in each section.
In the final analysis, the twenty kinds of wisdom mentioned above can be summarized as the two wisdoms of skillful means and reality.
As the sutra says:
The Tathagata's wisdom, insight, and skillful means are all complete, which comprehensively includes the various wisdoms of skillful means mentioned above.
The Tathagata's wisdom and insight are vast and profound, which comprehensively includes the wisdom of reality mentioned above.
Since skillful means are already complete, what is not included?
Since wisdom and insight are already vast and profound, what is not encompassed?
The realm is unfathomable, and the water of wisdom cannot measure it. Only the Buddhas can fully understand it.
Such wisdom and insight are the eye and wisdom.
The eye refers to the five eyes being complete, and the wisdom refers to the three wisdoms being one mind.
The knowledge of all modes knows the real, while the two knowledges know the expedient.
The Buddha eye sees the real, while the four eyes see the expedient.
This knowledge is precisely seeing, and this seeing is precisely knowledge.
Compared with the previous knowledges, those knowledges are coarse, while this knowledge and seeing are called subtle.
If one understands the meaning within knowledge and seeing, one does not discuss the five eyes again.
The deluded have not yet understood, so they further clarify the coarseness and subtlety of the eyes.
If the flesh eye is blind and closed, how can one see forms?
In vain one hears others speak and gives rise to various thoughts, but this is not true seeing.
If one wishes to open the eye, one should treat the film. How can one close the eyes and argue? What benefit is there?
The thoughts with closed eyes are coarse, while the seeing with open eyes is subtle.

If the heavenly eye is not yet open, not seeing what is beyond obstruction is coarse. Through the power of cultivating concentration and the knowledge of vows, one can give rise to pure form that penetrates inside and outside, with no obstruction of light or darkness.
The eye of wisdom is not yet open, and one always walks the path of death. Even if one has feelings and thoughts, they are also not real, so they are called coarse.
The pure and unobstructed mind suddenly arises, so it is called wonderful.
The truth is clearly understood, so it is called wonderful.
The eye of Dharma is not yet open, and one teaches the Dharma according to the differences in capacities.
Like ÅšÄriputra's biased teaching and PÅ«rá¹‡a's defiled vessel, it is called coarse.
Breaking through the obstacles and penetrating ignorance, distinguishing the medicine according to the illness, is called wonderful.
The Buddha eye is not yet open, and one does not see the true aspect.
Therefore, the text says:
The two vehicles, those newly giving rise to the mind, and non-regressing bodhisattvas are unable to know it, so the four eyes are all coarse.

Excluding the assembly of bodhisattvas whose power of faith is firm, by faith one is able to enter, and the similar Buddha eye is able to open the true Buddha's insight, which is then called wonderful.
Many teachings speak of the four eyes, or speak of the Buddha eye while still having the four eyes, and therefore it is coarse.
Now, this sutra alone speaks of the Buddha eye, and therefore it is wonderful.
This is called the wonderful in contrast to the coarse.
Sixth, clarifying the revelation of the coarse and the manifestation of the wonderful: The sixteen kinds of wisdom before, if not decisively understood, are merely coarse wisdom;
If one attains decisive understanding, they all become wonderful wisdom.
What is that?

Like King Wonderful Adornment, who was previously a worldly wise person outside the Way. Hearing the Lotus Sutra, he immediately attained decisive understanding. Using the characteristics of evil to enter the characteristics of the correct, he cultivated the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment without moving from the various views. Not abandoning the eight perversions, he entered the eight correct paths. This is precisely the decisive understanding of worldly wisdom, attaining entry into wonderful wisdom.
Either equal to the five categories, or equal to similarity, or equal to partial attainment, there are entries at each stage. The meaning is explained in detail.
If the wisdom of the five temporary expedient means, up to the wisdom of the Buddha in the Shared Teaching, if not decisively understood, it is coarse wisdom.
Now, revealing the real by opening the provisional, the path you are practicing is the bodhisattva path, you enter the wonderful position.
You must take the twelve kinds of wisdom and enter the wonderful four wisdoms of the perfect teaching, or enter the five ranks, similarity, partial attainment, and so forth.
Moreover, decisively understanding the wisdom of the separate teaching that is experienced sequentially, you enter the wonderful wisdom.
The essence itself is a certain position, and entering is a certain position. The details are explained.
The sixteen coarse wisdoms all become wonderful wisdom. There is no coarseness to be relied upon. This is the wonderful wisdom of transcendence.
Furthermore, opening the coarse eyes to become the wonderful eyes, although the other sutras speak of the five eyes, the five eyes are not fused, so they are coarse.
Now, this sutra decisively understands the four eyes and causes them to enter the Buddha eye.
The text says:
The eyes born from one's parents are then purified.
Those who study the Mahayana, although they have flesh eyes, are called the Buddha eye.
This is precisely the decisive understanding of the flesh eye, which is called the Buddha eye.
The Vimalakirti Sutra says:
Who in the world has the true heavenly eye? There is the World-Honored Buddha, who sees all Buddha lands without duality.
This is precisely the decisive understanding of the heavenly eye, which is the Buddha eye.
May I attain the wisdom eye, the foremost purity, like the World-Honored One, is the decisive understanding of the wisdom eye, which can enter the wonderful.
The decisive understanding of the Dharma eye entering the wonderful is the perfection of the ultimate wisdom.
The four eyes merge into the Buddha eye, quiescent yet always illuminating. Therefore, the text says:
Decisively understanding the Dharma of the Shravakas, it is the king of all sutras.
The five eyes are fully endowed, accomplishing enlightenment, and opening the Buddha's insight. Therefore, it is called wonderful.
Question:
Only when the Buddha eye is opened is it called wonderful.
Although the six sense faculties are purified, why is it called wonderful?
Answer:
Although the Buddha eye has not yet been opened, one is already able to study and believe in the perfect teaching.
It is like the kalaviá¹…ka bird, even though it is still in the egg, its voice is already superior to that of all other birds, this is the provisional name, similarity, and so forth of the wonderful.
If it hatches, it is the partial wonderful and the ultimate wonderful.
Second, clarifying wisdom in relation to objects, there are two parts:
First, relating to the five objects, second, mutually illuminating each other in relation to objects.
First, it should relate to the objects of the ten suchnesses. Since this is the meaning of the entire sutra, it is explained everywhere and can be understood, so it is not further explained.
Next, clarifying wisdom in relation to the four kinds of twelve links of dependent arising. The MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra says:
There are four kinds of contemplation of the twelve links of dependent arising:
Contemplating with inferior wisdom leads to the attainment of the enlightenment of the Å›rÄvakas.
Contemplating with middling wisdom leads to the attainment of the enlightenment of the pratyekabuddhas.
Contemplating with superior wisdom leads to the attainment of the enlightenment of the bodhisattvas.
Contemplating with the most superior wisdom leads to the attainment of the enlightenment of the buddhas.
What are they?
The twelve links of dependent origination are originally one realm, but due to different understandings, they are divided into four kinds.
Now, using the meaning of the four teachings to explain it:

The Tripiá¹­aka has all three kinds of people, but they all take the contemplation of the phenomena of the twelve links of dependent origination within the realm of desire using the wisdom of discernment as the initial approach.
However, the wisdom of discernment is shallow and weak, and among the three kinds of people, the Å›rÄvakas are the most inferior.
Using the inferior people to represent the shallow Dharma, it is called the wisdom of the inferior.

The Shared Teaching also has three kinds of people, who all use the wisdom of essence to contemplate the principle of the twelve links of dependent origination within the realm of desire. Although the essence of the Dharma is profound, compared to the Tripiá¹­aka it is skillful, but compared to the Distinct it is not yet skillful.
Among the three kinds of people, the pratyekabuddhas are in the middle.
Using the middle people to name the shared Dharma, it is called the wisdom of the middle.

In the Distinct Teaching, the Buddha and the bodhisattvas both know the phenomena of the twelve links of dependent origination outside the realm of desire. The bodhisattvas are not yet superior compared to the Buddha, but compared to the Shared and Tripiá¹­aka it is the superior Dharma, so the name of the superior wisdom is used.

In the Perfect Teaching, both Buddhas and Bodhisattvas contemplate the principle of the twelve links of dependent arising outside the three realms. From the initial stage, they are in the middle while being in phenomena.
This Dharma is the most supreme, so it is named after the Buddha. It is called the supreme wisdom contemplation.
Explaining the four contemplations with the four teachings, the meaning is in perfect agreement.

As for the lower wisdom contemplation, it contemplates that feeling is due to contact, contact is due to the six sense bases, the six sense bases are due to name-and-form, name-and-form is due to consciousness, consciousness is due to karmic formations, and karmic formations are due to ignorance.
Ignorance, delusion, and improper thoughts lead to unwholesome actions, resulting in the consciousness, name-and-form, and so forth of the four destinies.
If one has proper thoughts, it leads to wholesome actions, resulting in the consciousness, name-and-form, and so forth of humans and gods.
Contemplating this ignorance, moment by moment it is impermanent, with no abiding before or after.
The good and evil it produces quickly decays and perishes.
The name-and-form one receives changes and deteriorates.
Afflictions, karma, and suffering mutually cause each other, never stopping for a moment.
The two causes in the past and the five fruits in the present;
The three causes in the present and the two fruits in the future.
The three periods revolve like the wheel of a cart.
The root of deluded ignorance, since it is impermanent, suffering, empty, and without self, then ignorance ceases.
Because ignorance ceases, the various activities cease, up to old age and death cease.
If one does not light a fire, then there is no smoke. This is called severing the bondage of the child.
Without a child, there is no fruit. The ashes of extinguished wisdom leave the twenty-five existences. This is called severing the bondage of the fruit.
This is the lower wisdom observing the twelve links of dependent arising and attaining the enlightenment of the hearers.
The middling wisdom observes that feeling is due to contact, up to activity being due to ignorance.
Ignorance is just a single moment of deluded mind. The mind has no form or substance, it only has a name.
Inside, outside, and in between, one cannot find the character.
This character does not abide, nor does it not abide.
It is like an illusion, deceiving the eyes.
The essence and characteristics of ignorance are originally non-existent, arising from the combination of deluded thoughts and conditions.
Because it is non-existent, it is provisionally named ignorance.

Unskillful thoughts are created by the activities of the mind. Because one does not understand that ignorance is like an illusion, one gives rise to skillful and unskillful thoughts, then there are skillful and unskillful activities, and one experiences skillful and unskillful name-and-form, contact, and feeling.
Now, because one understands that ignorance is like an illusion, then all activities are also like transformations.
From the illusion, consciousness, name-and-form, and so forth are born, all like illusions.
